headline: One World with Zain Asher
subHeadline: Special Counsel Robert Hur Testifies About President Biden's Handling Of Classified Documents. Aired 12-1p ET

utterances.speaker: ROBERT HUR, SPECIAL COUNSEL
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I don't, I'm not here to testify about what will happen in the future.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: -- considering what I just laid out.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I'm here to I'm here to talk about the report and the work that went into it.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: But you don't want to be associated with that guy again, do you?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I'm not here to offer any opinions about what may or may not happen in the future. I'm here to talk about the work that went intothe report, which I stand by.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: There were no limits on you as to what you could charge President Biden by the attorney general. Is that right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: The decisions that I made that are reflected in the report are my own.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: And you did not bring any charges. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: There were no limits on John Durham and his investigation of the prior administration when he was special counsel. Is that right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I don't believe I have the information required to answer the question about the Durham investigation.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Well, he sat in the same Chair that you're sitting in. He told us that he also investigated President Biden and President Obama and did notbring any charges. President Biden sat for an interview with you over two days for approximately 10 hours. Is that right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: A little over five hours, Congressman.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Over two days.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: You know, that's in sharp contrast to a guy who did not sit for an interview when the Mueller investigation took place. That was DonaldTrump. Did not sit for an interview when he was impeached in this Committee room by the Judiciary Committee. Did not sit for an interview when the second impeachment occurred and he was invited to sit for an interview for his role in January 6th. And did not sit for an interview in the January 6th Classified -- in the January 6th case or the Classified Documents Case. Chairman also has not sat for an interview in his own subpoena, but Joe Biden has. I now want to turn you to the transcript and day one, page 47. You said to President Biden, you have -- appear to have a photographic understanding and recall of the House. Did you say that to President Biden?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Those words do appear on page 47 of the transcript.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Photographic is what you said. Is that right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That word does appear on page 47 of the transcript.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Never appeared in your report, though. Is that correct? The word photographic?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That does not appear in my report.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: I now want to show you and play a video of what is absolutely not photographic.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) DONALD TRUMP, FOREMER U.S. PRESIDENT, REPUBLICAN PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: In the failing "New York Times" by an anonymous, really an anonymous, gutless coward. We are a nation that just recently heard that Saudi Arabia and Russia will repeat -- I hope they now go and take a look at the oranges -- the oranges of the investigation. And I watch our police and our firemen down on 7-11, down the World Trade Center. And we did with Obama. We won an election that everyone said couldn't be won. This is the very definition of totalitarianism. And let me begin by wishing you a beautiful look. You remember this? Do you remember? God bless the United States. The windmills are driving them crazy. They're driving -- they're driving the whales, I think, a little batty. And I went to Puerto Rico and I met with the President of the - JIM JORDAN, (R-OH) U.S. REPRESENTATIVE: The gentleman yields back. The Chair now recognizes the gentleman from North Carolina. DAN BISHOP, U.S. HOUSE REPUBLICAN: S Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Mr. Hur, I'm way down here in the end of the dais. I think today, the Justice Department released the transcripts of the interviews with President Biden. Are you aware of that?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I understand that to be true. Yes.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Did you have any involvement in the decision or the timing of the release of the transcripts?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No, Congressman.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Did you make any recommendation about the release of the transcripts for being done or not?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I did not. That was above my pay grade.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, the report reflects our best efforts to summarize and characterize the evidence in the investigation, including the investigationreceived from the President himself during our interview of him. But as you point out, the transcripts of the President's interview over two days are now available to the Committee for their inspection. And the members are able to draw their own conclusions based on the transcripts that are now available to them.

utterances.speaker: BISHOP
utterances.sentences: Well, with all -- and I appreciate your answer. And I certainly think things, you know, you can come up with some details that someone candisagree on. And it has the quality, I know, of some of some cherry-picking because I've just found something. But we've only had a little bit of time to look. I don't think it serves this process well for the Justice Department to dump these transcripts into the public right now. If they were going to be released, they should have been released at a proper time. And I think I'll leave it at that, Mr. Chairman. I'll yield back.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The gentleman will yield. The gentleman will yield.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I will yield to the gentleman.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Just real quick, Mr. Hur, someone earlier said, you know, said something about changing the facts. You said, I'm not going to change thefacts, but let's keep the facts the same, but change the subject. If you had the same facts and the individual that you were investigating was 65 and had a good memory, do you reach the same conclusion?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, as I responded earlier to a question along these lines, I am not here to entertain hypotheticals about facts or circumstances thatmay be different. What I did was assess the evidence and the facts that I obtained in this investigation and make a judgment based on this set of evidence.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes, Congresswoman.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: And your 15-month investigation cost several million dollars and resulted in a comprehensive 345-page report with several dozen pages ofappendices. Is it correct that, as it says in the first sentence of your executive summary, that your investigation concluded with an assessment that, quote, "No criminal charges are warranted in this matter"?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: So, this lengthy, expensive, and independent investigation resulted in a complete exoneration of President Joe Biden. For everydocument you discussed in your report, you found insufficient evidence that the President violated any laws about possession or retention of classified materials. The primary law that you analyzed for potential prosecution was part of the Espionage Act, 18 U.S.C. 793E, which criminalizes willful retention or disclosure of national defense information. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congresswoman, that is one statute that we analyzed. I need to go back and make sure that I take note of the word that you used -- "exoneration".That is not a word used in my report. That's not part of my task.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: Mr. Hur, I'm going to continue with my questions. I' going to continue with my question. I know that the term -- I know that the term --

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That is not a word used in my report -- the judgment that I ultimately reached whether sufficient evidence existed such that the likely outcomewould be a conviction.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: You didn't -- you exonerated.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: I know that the term, "willfull retention" has a --

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I did not exonerate him. That word does not appear in the report, Congresswoman.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: Mr. Hur, it's my time. Thank you. I know that the term "willfull retention" has a particular legal meaning and I want to make sure that thatmeaning is absolutely clear to the American people before we go any further. As you wrote in your report, to prove as a matter of law that the President, quote, "willfully retained any documents", you would need to prove, beyond a reasonable doubt, two elements. First, that the President knowingly retained or disclosed national defense information, and second, that he knew that this conduct was unlawful. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That's correct.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: And to be very, very --

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Oh and I'm sorry, Congresswoman. That was national defense information. That's an important third element.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: Okay, thank you. To be very, very clear, you did not find sufficient evidence to prove either of those elements, beyond a reasonabledoubt, to show that Mr. Biden willfully retained any of the classified national defense materials that were recovered during your investigation, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: My conclusion was that the admissible evidence was not sufficient to make conviction at trial a probable outcome.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: Not sufficient. Thank you. Let me ask you about a few specific examples so the American people are clear. One set of documents wasdiscovered by investigators in the President's Delaware home. His staff had assembled those documents into binders in 2014 to prepare him for an event with Charlie Rose. Some of the documents in those binders were marked "Classified". You reviewed all of the facts surrounding the classified documents in those binders, and you determined, and this is a quote from your report, "These facts do not support a conclusion that Mr. Biden willfully retained the marked "Classified" documents in these binders, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That language does appear in the report.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: You also reviewed another set of classified documents from the President's home related to the Afghanistan troop surge in 2009, and youevaluated whether the President willfully retained such documents in his Delaware home or a home that he rented in Virginia in 2017. In your report, you said that there was, quote, "a shortage of evidence", end quote, "for any wrongdoing", end quote, "other innocent explanations for the documents that we cannot refute", end quote. Are those quotes correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congresswoman, if you have particular page sites for those quotations, I'd be happy to confirm their accuracy.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: Page six. It's right up on the screen.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: With respect to the two quotes that are on the screen, in addition to this shortage of evidence, there are other innocent explanations fordocuments we cannot refute, and we conclude the evidence is not sufficient to convict, and we decline to recommend prosecution --

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: I was just going to get to that. And you concluded that, quote, "The evidence is not sufficient to convict, and we decline to recommendprosecution." End quote. Those are your words in the report, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Those words appear in the report.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: Thank you. President Biden's counsel discovered a different set of documents at the Penn-Biden Center and voluntarily turned them over to theFBI. Those documents contain national security information, but you determined that you could not, in fact, prove that President Biden willfully retained those documents because, quote, "The evidence suggests that the marked "Classified" documents found at the Penn-Biden Center were sent and kept there by mistake. Therefore, we decline -- "We decline any criminal charges related to those documents", end quote. Correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: The language, "We decline any criminal charges related to those documents" does appear at page 311 of the report.

utterances.speaker: JAYAPAL
utterances.sentences: Thank you. You also reached a similar conclusion regarding the documents found in President Biden's Senate papers at the University ofDelaware. Quote, "For these reasons, it is likely that the few "Classified" documents found in Mr. Biden's Senate papers at the University of Delaware were there by mistake, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That language does appear at page 325 of the report.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The gentle lady yields back. The gentle lady from Indiana is recognized.VICTORIA SPARTZ, U.S. HOUSE REPUBLICAN: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I just thank you, Special Counsel, for being here in these challenging times. And I want to tell you a few things that is interesting for me. You obviously could see that there is a motive, there is a legacy. You obviously see that it was a willful retention of these documents. But it's interesting for me that when you talk about sympathetic, well- meaning, older man who has poor - elderly man who has a poor memory, it seems like every, you know, attorney would advise you to be sympathetic and be well-meaning. And it seems like the whole FBI needs to do -- based on my hearings here, I need to do check on amnesia because everyone says doesn't recall. So, it seems to me that it might have been something way more in his recollection that's the the typical -- I don't recall. Because that's what everything is like. That's what I've learned here. So, is there something more than that? That just I don't recall something for you to actually decide? Because it seems like this is the core of the whole investigation. Why didn't you pursue further -- the charges?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congresswoman, my judgment as to how a jury would likely perceive and receive and consider evidence relating to -- relating to all the all theevidence that would be put in by both the government and the defense at trial, it was based on a number of different sources -- from documents, including various recordings, some of them from the 2016-2017 time frame, some from our interview with the President in October of 2023. I think what you're asking about specifically is how the President presented himself during his interview in October of last year. And of course, I did take into account not just the words from the cold record of the transcript, but the entire manner in living color, in real time, of how the President presented himself during his interview.

utterances.speaker: SPARTZ
utterances.sentences: Hopefully, he didn't smart you and all of us. But before I yield, I just wanted to actually just comment on something, you know, Mr. Raskinmentioned about us not remembering communists. I actually grew up under communists, and I have a very good recollection of what it is. And unfortunately, Tehran's eye on the rise, on the march, which he said, unfortunately, they've been emboldened by, you know, President Obama, now by President Biden, too. And unfortunately, our government and Department of Justice really now resembles a tyrannical government. It's sad for me to see that. But I'm going in with a really double standard, what we have there. But I'm going to yield to Chairman Jordan the rest of my time.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Thank the gentle lady for yielding. Mr. Hur, during your one-year investigation, did you have communications with the White House and theWhite House Counsel in particular?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: I think you had like, I got five letters that they -- and they communicated with you regarding your investigation. Is that accurate?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: We received a number of letters from White House Counsel's office and -- as well as the President's personal counsel.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Right. They're either special counsel or personal counsel, I see, who signed the letters. And did the White House get the report before thereport was made public?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: We did provide a draft of the report to the White House Counsel's office and members of the President's personal counsel team for theirreview.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: No, I understand. And did the White House then -- once they got the report before it went public, did the White House try to weigh in with yourinvestigation on elements of that report? And, frankly, get the report changed?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: They did request certain edits and changes to the draft report.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Yeah, I see that in the the February 5th letter. Did they only correspond with you?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, Congressman, are you -- are you asking if they -- Congress -- if they corresponded with anyone else on my team?

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Once you gave the report to the White House --

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: They tried to -- they saw changes. I have one letter here that's addressed to you on February 5th, and they said we're pleased that aftermore of your -- of investigating, you've determined, you know, they'd respond to the report. And then they asked -- they disagree with your -- they asked for you to change some of the things you had in your report, namely the fact that the President's memory was not very good. Do you remember that?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes, Sir.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Okay. But I also have two other letters, one on February 7th to Merrick Garland, where they raised the same concern, and then on February12th, where they go to the DAG. Bradley Weinsheimer. You familiar with those?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I am familiar with those letters, Bradley Weinsheimer is an assistant or Associate Deputy Attorney General.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Right. Associate DAG. The ADAG, right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.Jordan: And Merrick Garland, of course, is the attorney general.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes and yes.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: So, you're familiar with the fact that they went over your head?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: They were certainly entitled to write whatever letters they wished to Mr. Weinsheimer and to the attorney general.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: I just find that interesting. The White House is -- they're communicating with you throughout this one-year investigation, and then theWhite House says, oh, we're going to --we're going to go to the -- we're going to go to the Principal's Office, and we're going to -- we're going to talk about Mr. Hur's report. Do you find that interesting?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: As I said, they were free to correspond with whomever in the federal government they wished to correspond with. I did engage in numerouscommunications with them during the course of the investigation, and as is reflected in the special counsel regulations, the attorney general did provide oversight of my investigation.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: We identified no such evidence.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: Did you find that President Biden directed his lawyer to destroy classified documents?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: Did you find that President Biden directed his personal assistant to move boxes of documents to hide them from the FBI?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: Did you find that President Biden directed his personal assistant to delete security camera footage after the FBI asked for that footage?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No. Did you find that President Biden showed a classified map related to an ongoing military operation to a campaign aide who did not haveclearance?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: Did you find that President Biden engaged in a conspiracy to obstruct justice?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: Did you find that President Biden engaged in a scheme to conceal?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: Each of the activities I just laid out describe what Donald Trump did in his willful mishandling of classified information and his criminalefforts to deceive the FBI. In contrast, President Biden handed over documents without delay and complied fully with investigators. Mr. Hur, in your report, you write that, quote, "According to indictment, Trump not only refused to return the documents for many months, but he also obstructed justice by enlisting others to destroy evidence and then to lie about it," end quote. You also say that if proven, these would be, quote, "serious, aggravating facts," end quote. Do you still stand by your analysis?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: Okay. I have a few more questions, as well. In your investigation, did you find that President Biden set up a shell company and covertly paid$130,000 in hush money to an adult porn star?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: Did you find that President Biden directed his lawyer to pay $150,000 in hush money to a former Playboy model?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: In your investigation, did you find that President Biden called the Georgia Secretary of State to demand that he, quote, "Find 11,780 votes?"

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: Did you find that President Biden devised a scheme to organize a slate of fake electors to undermine a free and fair election?

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: No. Did you find that leading up to January 6, 2021, President Biden urged his supporters to travel to D.C. and to storm the Capitol?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: LIEU
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Each of these activities I laid out describe what Donald Trump did, his efforts to bully election officials, overthrow the resultsof the election, and deceive the American people. That is why Donald Trump has been indicted in not just one, not just two, not just three, but four criminal cases. I yield back.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Gentleman yields back. The gentleman from Wisconsin is recognized for five minutes.TOM TIFFANY, U.S. HOUSE REPUBLICAN: I just want to go do a little repetition, Mr. Hur, in regards to the Chairman's questions from a few minutes ago. So, is it correct that on that February 5th letter that was sent to you, asking you to change references to the president's poor memory, wasn't there a request by the White House to do that?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: There was a request, yes.

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: And, Mr. Chairman, I think the record should show that the gentleman from Maryland earlier said that that was not the case. I think hesaid, "nor did he seek to redact a single word of Hur's report". Obviously, Mr. Hur is telling us differently here. And didn't the White House then go to the attorney general himself and say that he would like to see changes to the references in regards to the President's memory?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: The White House counsel did send such a letter.Tiffany: So, if this President was 60 years old rather than 80 years old, would you prosecute him?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, as I've said before, I cannot engage in hypotheticals. I address the facts and the evidence as I found them in this matter.

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: So, there was an 80-year-old grandma that came to Washington, D.C. a few years ago, did not commit a violent crime, committed a crime, but didnot commit a violent crime, and she was fully prosecuted. Doesn't that seem like it's a dual system of justice where the President is above the law?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I don't know the facts and the details of this other case that you're referencing with this other person.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I believe that's in Chapter 13.

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: How so? How is he unlikely to reoffend in the future? How do you come to that judgment?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: As I say on page 254, any deterrent effect of prosecution would likely be slight. We are not concerned with specific deterrents. As we see littlerisk, he will reoffend.

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: Well, isn't it because he's now the President and he has almost unlimited authority to release documents? Isn't that correct? I mean, as aVice President, he didn't have that authority. Now that he's President, isn't it easy to say that, that he's unlikely to reoffend because he's got almost unlimited authority to release these documents?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Well, that statement was based on -- that assessment of the likeliness of reoffending from this particular person, President Biden, is based on anumber of factors, including the authority that he has now with respect to classified materials, as well as the experience that he's had going through a special counsel investigation.

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: Yeah, but look at back at 2011, there were multiple instances where he was informed by staff and they ratcheted it up to where there wasa formal process. You're saying he's learned from that when he's proven that he hasn't? I mean, that goes all the way back to 2011.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, what I'm saying in the report at page 254 is that --

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: He's a repeat offender, Mr. Hur, isn't he?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: What I say --

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: Let me move on to -- I'll move on to something else here. You said he had strong motivations to ignore the proper procedures for safeguardingclassified information. And he provided raw material to his ghostwriter that would be of interest to perspective readers and buyers of his book. And I think you said something about he viewed himself as a historic figure, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I believe those words do all appear in the report.

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And he was also doing this for business purposes, that there may be people that would want to buy his book.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Towards the end of his vice presidency, Mr. Biden had resolved to write a book and began work on it towards the end of his vice presidency.

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: You know, I think, Mr. Chairman, this is really consistent with the Biden family. When you look at them in trying to enrich themselves, Imean, you're familiar with the work that the Oversight Committee has done over the last year, right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I have read some reports of it.

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: I mean, 20 phone calls that were made to his son that he denied in 2019, 20 shell companies that were created, over $20 million. I mean,doesn't it appear there's a pattern here that where I come from, they almost call it money grubbing.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, what I'm here to testify about today is the work that I conducted in this investigation and in this report.

utterances.speaker: TIFFANY
utterances.sentences: So, I want to thank you for the work that you did as far as you could. But unfortunately, you are part of the Praetorian Guard that guardsthe swamp out here in Washington, D.C., protecting the elites. And Joe Biden is part of that company of the elites. And you see it in the things that the Department of Justice has not acted on, Mr. Chairman. I mean, you look at the President's son, who does not have to answer for lying on his Form 4473 in regards to throwing away a weapon. You see it where the Department of Justice fends off the IRS when the whistleblowers come with this information. Now, we see it once again, where a President believes he is above the law. And there is no doubt that this President does believe he's above the law. I yield back, Mr. Chairman.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Gentlemen yields back. The gentleman from California is recognized.LOU CORREA, U.S. HOUSE DEMOCRAT: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Mr. Hur, welcome. I also concur. And let me echo what's already been said by my colleagues that your personal story of being an immigrant, your family immigrants to this country, the way you've contributed to the greatness of this country shows why America is great. The Great Immigrant Story. Thank you for being here, Sir. First question to you is, you're a Republican?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I am, Sir.

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: Does that stop you from a thorough and fair investigation?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I certainly hope not. And I know not.

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: This story is really proof of the old saying that the cover up is worse than the crime. President Trump and President Biden handled theirclassified materials differently, wouldn't you say?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: My report includes an assessment of the alleged facts in the pending indictment of former President Trump and a comparison to the facts that wefound in this case.

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: But clearly the handling of these documents was night and day, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, do you have a specific aspect of the handling of the documents that you have in mind?

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, President Trump intentionally took classified materials and obstructed justice to ensure that those materials wouldn't betaken from him. And he refused to work with law enforcement. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: My report reflects no findings of obstructive conduct on the part of - -

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I don't know the exact number of counts, but I know that an indictment is pending in that district.

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: Mr. Hur, you even wrote that after being given a number of chances to return classified documents and avoid prosecution, Mr.- I should sayPresident Trump allegedly did oppose. And according to the indictment, he not only refused to return those documents over for many months, but he also obstructed justice by enlisting others to destroy evidence and lie about them. Compare and contrasting the President Trump, President Trump turned classified documents over to the National Archives and the Department of Justice. And he consented to searching his home and other locations. Wouldn't you say that's night and day when it comes to cooperation with law enforcement?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, the report does include an analysis and a comparison of the facts that are alleged with respect to former President Trump and doesdetail steps of cooperation that the President and his team took with respect to my investigation.

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: I would say -- President Biden, you had his full cooperation in this investigation.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: The report includes cooperative steps that the President took.

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: Would this be a factor in your decision to prosecute?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: It was a factor, and I explained it as such in the report, Congressman.

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: And you stated that the recommendation not to prosecute had nothing to do with the Department of Justice policy not to indict the sittingPresident. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: What the report says that even if it were not current Department of Justice policy that a sitting President may not be indicted on federalcrimes, I would reach the same conclusion that criminal charges are not warranted.

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: Mr. Hur, have you set new precedent here today?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: To the extent that -- to the extent that the Department of Justice makes enforcement decisions or non-enforcement decisions in particularcases, those are precedents. Those are those are events that future prosecutors do look to in an endeavor to make sure that law -- federal law is implied consistently over time.

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: Mr. Hur, I'd say based on your education and your career experience, you're a very, very competent prosecutor, a very, very well-prepared attorney. I'm going to ask you one more time. Does the fact that you're Republican, does that stop you from a thorough and fair investigation?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No. Partisan politics had nothing to do with the work that I did or the report that I wrote or the decision that I reached.

utterances.speaker: CORREA
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much for being here. And Mr. Chairman, I yield.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Gentleman yields back. Gentleman from Wisconsin is recognized.SCOTT FITZGERALD, U.S. HOUSE REPUBLICAN: Attorney Hur, Webster's dictionary defines senile as exhibiting a decline of cognitive ability, such as memory associated with old age. Mr. Hur, based on your report, did you find that the President was senile?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I did not. That conclusion does not appear in my report, Congressman.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: But you felt, though, that the President's memory or lack thereof was a critical reason to decline prosecution. The reason I'm askingthis is whether you believe the President would be fit to stand trial, or do you think his lawyers would argue his incompetence to stand trial due to his state of mind? Also, you know, was he in a place to actually be questioned?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, my report, to the extent that it addresses the President's memory gaps that we identified in the evidence that we obtainedduring our investigation, they are addressed in the context of determining how the jury would perceive, receive, and consider evidence relating to whether or not the President had willful intent when it came to retaining or disclosing national defense information.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: Very good. I'd like to focus my questioning on Chapter 14 of your report, the classified documents found at the Penn-Biden Center. Youstate in your report that the documents found at the Penn-Biden Center were the most highly classified, sensitive, and compartmentalized materials recovered during your investigation. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That is correct.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: Many of the documents came from Mr. Biden's West Wing office. That's also correct, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I believe that is reflected in the report.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: Did you ask if he had packed the boxes himself?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I believe that was one of the questions that we asked, and that is reflected in the transcript now available to the Committee.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: I think it's important. How would you characterize the packing of these boxes? Was it slow and meticulous, or were they packed in hastewithout much scrutiny at all?

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: Very good. According to your report, the boxes were moved between multiple offices, between Mr. Biden departing his West Wing officein January of 17 and his arrival at the Penn-Biden Center's permanent offices in October of 17. Were any of these offices authorized to store classified information?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: When the boxes finally arrived at the Penn-Biden Center's permanent offices, how were they stored?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I believe when the materials were recovered, some of them were stored in a storage closet. And I believe others of them were in file cabinetdrawers. So I would refer you to the report.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: What's your assessment of security and access control measures at the Penn-Biden Center?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That was something that we looked at. There were some security access controls at the Penn-Biden Center, but we did get a handle on people whohad access to the office space during the time period when we believed the materials were there. And there were other people, including students and some foreign dignitaries that visited that facility at the time.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: Very good. You anticipated my next question. So, when the boxes were discovered to have classified documents more than five years later,who discovered these boxes? It was Patrick Moore. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct. One of the President's personal counsel.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: And did Mr. Moore have some type of active security clearance at the time

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.Fitzgerald: How about the executive assistant at the Penn-Biden Center?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: On page 265 of your report --

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, Congressman. I may have misspoken there. I am not certain whether or not that executive assistant had an active security clearance atthe time.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: Very good. On page 265 of your report, you stated, when interviewed by FBI agents, Moore believed the small closet was initiallylocked and that the Penn-Biden Center staff member provided a key to unlock it. But his memory was fuzzy on that point. But an interview with Mr. Biden's executive assistant seemed to contradict his statement. Do you remember this exchange? And did, in fact, it contradict each other?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Sir, you're asking if I remember the exchange with Mr. Moore during our interview with him?

utterances.speaker: FITZGRERALD
utterances.sentences: Right. Do you remember them contradicting each other?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I don't remember that contradiction specifically. But generally, during the interview, sometimes we heard things from some witnesses thatwere in tension with what we heard from other witnesses. And we did our best to resolve those conflicts.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: Just very quickly, in total, the National Archives discovered nine documents totaling 144 pages with classification markings. Is thatcorrect?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: From the Penn-Biden Center. Yes.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: And you declined charges because, in summarizing your analysis, you couldn't prove beyond a reasonable doubt that retention of thedocuments was willful.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct, Sir.

utterances.speaker: FITZGERALD
utterances.sentences: Very good. I yield back.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Gentleman yields back. Gentle lady from Pennsylvania is recognized.MARY GAY SCANLON, U.S. HOUSE DEMOCRAT: Thank you. And thank you, Mr. Hur, for your testimony today. With all the posturing that we've heard thus far this morning, I think it's important that we refocus and remember the conclusion that you reached on the first page. And in the very first sentence of your report, which was, we conclude that no criminal charges are warranted in this matter. Did I read that accurately?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: You did, Congresswoman.

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.sentences: Okay. Your report also says, in addition to this shortage of evidence, there are other innocent explanations for the documents that wehave not been able to refute. Did I read that correctly?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congresswoman, if you would give me a page citation, I can --

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.sentences: Page six

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Six. Yes, I see that language on page six.

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.sentences: Okay, thank you. Now, in addition to those conclusions, your report details several material distinctions, as you called them, betweenPresident Biden's actions and former President Trump's mishandling of classified materials. The facts are that President Biden cooperated with your investigation. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: He did.

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.sentences: And his team notified authorities when they discovered classified documents, and he turned them over immediately. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.sentences: He consented to multiple searches of his home and other properties. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.sentences: And he voluntarily sat for an interview with you. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct. But when it comes to Mr. Trump's treatment of classified materials, your report states that, according to the criminal indictmentagainst him, he refused to return classified documents in his possession for many months, despite having multiple chances to do so, and he obstructed justice by enlisting others to destroy evidence and lie about it. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Your next wife was a woman by the name of Marla Maples.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: And sitting here today, do you recall what years you were married to Ms. Maples?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'd have to get the exact dates for you. I can do that.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Am I correct that you married your current wife in January 2005?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't know relative to that date.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: And what years were you the owner of the Paz Hotel?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't know the years.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: James Webb.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't remember the names. I don't remember the name.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: So, you don't remember saying you were one of the best men in the world?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't remember that. I remember you telling me, but I don't know the answer.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.sentences: So, I would also add that Mr. Trump told lawyers, "I don't remember" 35 times in his deposition for a lawsuit over Trump University.And in response to questions from special counsel Robert Mueller, he answered, "did not remember" or "could not recall" 27 times. Now, Mr. Hur, you've said today that DOJ process and regulations required you to assess whether a jury would find Mr. Biden to be a credible witness, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure that I said those words exactly. But of course, in my view, how a jury would perceive Mr. Biden if he elected to testify in hisown defense at a trial, that would be part of the whole ball of wax that jurors would consider in determining whether he had willful intent in retaining or disclosing national defense information.

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.sentences: Sure. Do you have any reason to believe that the special counsel who investigated and charged Mr. Trump with willful retention of classifieddocuments would have failed to make an assessment of whether the jury would find Mr. Trump to be a credible witness?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I don't, I don't have any information relating to what, how, I'm not qualified basically to answer that question as to what went into Mr.Smith's decision-making. But you are qualified to say what are the normal procedures followed by a special counsel, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I'm familiar with the rules that set forth in the justice manual and my understanding of how to apply them.

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.sentences: And in fact, what you did.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: SCANLON
utterances.sentences: Okay. So, I would suggest that we can all assume that the fact that Mr. Trump was charged with multiple counts of willfully concealingclassified documents suggests that the special counsel in that case determined that Mr. Trump's denials are not credible. At this point, I would ask unanimous consent to enter into the record an excerpt from the Committee's transcribed interview with Steven D'Antonio, former assistant director in charge of the FBI Washington field office on July 7th, 2023, in which he explained the urgency for the FBI to retrieve and secure classified documents from Donald Trump's estate because they contained national security information that should not be viewed by anyone without the proper security clearance. Even Mr. D'Antonio himself could not view the documents given their high security clearance, despite being the assistant director in charge of the FBI Washington field office. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Without objection, the gentle lady yields back. The gentleman from Oregon is recognized for five minutes.CLIFF BENTZ, U.S. HOUSE REPUBLICAN: Thank you, Mr. Chair. I'm quite interested in the dates that are set forth in your report, Mr. Hur. And the reason I'm interested is because I keep getting confused between the 2017 date and the 2024 date as to the condition of the President's memory. And so, was there a difference? Because when I look at it, it seems like his memory was bad in 2017, and then it was bad today. But there's never any distinction made. But isn't it true that if you were going to be looking at his, at prosecuting as you were, you would look carefully at his condition in 2017? Isn't that the proper time? Because I think you say in your report that the most, your best case, I think you call it out, the best case for charges would rely on Mr. Biden's possession of Afghanistan documents in his Virginia home in February 2017, when he was a private citizen. And when he told this ghostwriter, he just found classified material. That's the best case as you say it.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BENTZ
utterances.sentences: And then you work your way through a series of defenses against your best case. So, you were looking at his condition in 2017. Do I have thatright?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: You do, Congressman.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I did not. Those words do not appear in my report.

utterances.speaker: BENTZ
utterances.sentences: They do not. But you reached a conclusion that you didn't have the evidence. But then your report continually recites these defenses. I'mhaving a hard time putting the two together. If you didn't have the evidence, why do you persist in reciting these defenses?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I wrote my report as an explanation of my decision to decline charges as to President Biden. And the way that I came up with thatexplanation and wrote it in my report for the attorney general is the following. The approach that I took was a prosecutor envisioning what would be the probable outcome of trial if we charged this case, if we presented the evidence to a jury, and not only the government presenting the evidence to a jury, but what would happen if the defense lawyers also got a chance to try to poke holes in the government's case at trial. And with respect to one of the several potential defenses that I lay out in the report, one of them does focus on the President's memory-related issues. That is a defense that the President's defense lawyers may well present at trial. And a jury is going to be confronted with at least three separate sets of evidence relating to the President's memory. One is from the recordings in 2016 and 2017 from the ghostwriter.

utterances.speaker: BENTZ
utterances.sentences: Forgive me for interrupting, but I'm limited on time as everybody else was. But you say, I think, that the evidence suggests he is incapableof forming or you're incapable of proving intent. There's kind of a bit of a difference there, right? You may well have had the intent, but you could not prove of holding these documents and, I hate to say, hiding the documents. But you couldn't prove it. So, what you did instead is fell back to the various defenses that might also be asserted against you. Kind of a heap of rationale for not pursuing the President. Do I have it right now?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I think we're on the same page. I think what I'm trying to convey is that the way that prosecutors assess the strengths andweaknesses of their case is to think through, hey, in the government's case in chief, here's the evidence we're going to present, and the jury might be with us. But that's not the end of the trial. The trial also has to include presentation from the defense lawyers. You're correct, and I'm a lawyer. I've tried cases, so I get it. But your report is not an exoneration so much as a determination that the evidence, as you saw it, would not overcome the defenses that you had identified, plus whatever lack of evidence you perceived. So, it's not an exoneration, is it?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: The word exoneration does not appear anywhere in my report, and that is not my conclusion.

utterances.speaker: BENTZ
utterances.sentences: The other thing that's of interest, and I think you were misquoted, you said something about, or someone, I think it was Mr. Raskin, suggestedthat you, well, I'm going to run out of time, but I appreciate the work you do as a prosecutor and I yield back.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The gentleman yields back. Mr. Hur, we've been at this close to three hours. If you can hang with us, we'd like to keep going. There's achance we could complete votes by the time we have to go to votes on the House floor, which would be about 140. I can keep going, Chairman.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Okay, then we'll try to do that. There's a chance we may not, too, but I just wanted you to know the lay of the land. Now, I yield to thegentleman from Colorado. JOE NEGUSE, U.S. HOUSE DEMOCRAT: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Thank you, Mr. Hur for your testimony and for your service as a prosecutor at the Department of Justice. I want to focus a bit more on the progress of the investigation and some process questions. So, you were appointed by Attorney General Garland as special counsel to investigate the President's handling of classified documents in January of 2023, correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: And Attorney General Garland, of course, as you know, was nominated by President Biden to serve in his role.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: During your 15-month investigation, did the Attorney General attempt to interfere with your investigation?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: Did he impede your investigation in any way?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: Did any other member of the Department of Justice or within the administration refuse to cooperate with your investigation?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: Were you ever denied access to materials, witnesses, resources from Attorney General Garland that you might have needed during theinvestigation?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: You submitted, I think this is right, your final report to Attorney General Garland on February 5th of 2024.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: Okay. And it was then released publicly three days later on February 8th of 2024. Is that right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I believe that's true, yes.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: In the final report that was released, were any of your substantive findings redacted or changed in any way?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: None of your findings were modified by the Attorney General?

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: Did the Attorney General issue any kind of statement or a letter attempting to describe the contents of your report?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: Okay. You're familiar, I know, I'm sure, with the investigation that was conducted by Special Counsel Mueller years ago with respect to theformer President?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: And at that time, Attorney General Barr was in charge of the Justice Department. He sat where you sat in this Committee, I remember itwell, just a few short years ago, testifying on the nature of that particular investigation. Are you familiar with the way in which he released that report and characterized it?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: Okay. Very different from the way that Attorney General Garland conducted this particular release. I take it you'd agree with that.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: They were not the same approach.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: Not the same approach. Right. In the case of Attorney General Garland, no impeding or interfering with your investigation in any waywhatsoever, releasing the report in full to the American public, not attempting to mischaracterize it or describe it in any way. Dissimilar from Attorney General Barr, who five years ago, as you recall, after Special Counsel Mueller submitted his report to the Department of Justice, took nearly a month to release the report to the American public, heavily redacted, and not before he had issued a letter of his own to the leaders of the Senate and House Judiciary Committees, mischaracterizing the contents of that report. That distinction and difference is very important because from your testimony, at least from what I gleaned from your testimony, is that Attorney General Garland acted appropriately and ethically with respect to this investigation. I take it you agree.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Attorney General Garland did not interfere with my efforts, and I was able to conduct a fair, thorough, and independent investigation.

utterances.speaker: NEGUSE
utterances.sentences: Very different approach, as you said, from the way in which the Department of Justice unfortunately, tragically, functioned under theformer President. I'm going to yield back the balance of my time.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: The gentleman yields back. The gentleman from Alabama is recognized for five minutes. Would the gentleman yield for 10 seconds?BARRY MOORE, U.S. HOUSE REPUBLICAN: Yes, Sir.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: I would just point out to the gentleman from Colorado's last point, there was one big difference. Bill Barr didn't name Bob Mueller as aspecial counsel. Bob Mueller was named by Rod Rosenstein. That's a huge difference in how this whole thing works. I now yield back to the gentleman from Alabama.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Mr. Hur, in your report, you cited principles of federal prosecution and observed that, and I quote,"Historically, after leaving office, many former Presidents and Vice Presidents have knowingly taken home sensitive materials related to national security for their administrations without being charged with crimes. And this historical record is important context for judging whether or why to charge a former Vice President or and our former President," unquote. Why is examining this history so important?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, one of the reasons that it was important was because it would bear on how a jury would perceive -- how a jury would decide whetheror not criminal willful intent was formed by the person retaining or disclosing the national defense information at issue.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Has there been an exception to this in the history of the nation? Have we charged any former Presidents?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: As I state in the report, to my knowledge, there is only one exception, and that is former President Trump.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Given the history, is it fair to say it's preferable not to charge a former President or Vice President for allegedly mishandling classifieddocuments, in your opinion?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I can't articulate a preference. Whether it's preferable, all I can talk about is the work that I did, the facts that I found, andthe decision that I reached in my case.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Hur, what's the difference in the U.S. Senator having documents and a former President of the United States?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: For purposes of proving willfulness, I believe that there would be a number of differences in terms of the types of access and the ease withwhich Presidents, while in office, can access classified information as compared to the access privileges that senators have.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Can Presidents declassify documents that they have in their possession?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I believe under certain circumstances, yes.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Former Presidents, as well?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman, I confess I'm not -- this is not an area of the law that I've looked into or explained in my report, and I'm here to talk about thework that is reflected in the report.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Well, let me say this, Sir. You have a reputation beyond reproach, and I just want you to know that. And I think that President Biden ought tobe thankful that the attorney general appointed you to investigate his case. But you have a special counsel colleague by the name of Jack Smith who cannot lay claim to such a reputation. Isn't that right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I have no opinion. I don't have anything to say about that.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Sir, I'm not here to express any opinions with respect to a pending case against another defendant. I was, I'm here to talk about the work thatI did with respect to the investigation relating to President Biden.

utterances.speaker: MOORE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Chairman, I yield the balance of my time back to you.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Thank you. To this conclusion.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congressman Jordan, I'm sorry, the mic was turned on.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Can you explain what specifically in your interview with President Biden led you to this conclusion?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: The conclusion about --

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: A broad statement that's been cited many times.

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: The totality of the time that I spent with the President during his voluntary interview was something that I certainly considered in framing myassessment and articulating in the report. And that includes not only the words in the cold record of the transcript of the interview, but also the experience of being there in the room with him. And frankly, considering how he would present to a jury in a criminal trial if charges were brought.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: And I guess I'm asking specifically, I know you cited in the report, the dates that he couldn't remember when he was Vice President,when he began, when his term ended, you cite that in report. Is there anything else specifically that stands out from that interview with the President?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: A number of things stand out. And again, I'm aware that the transcript has now been made available. I do provide certain examples in my report ofsignificant, personally painful experiences about which the President was unable to recall certain information. I also took into account the President's overall demeanor in interacting with me during the five plus hour voluntary interview. So, it was a wealth of details about being there in the moment with the President, including his inability to recall certain things. And I'll also say, as reflected in the transcript, the fact that he was prompted on numerous occasions by the members of the White House counsel's office.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: I read that. The brief look I had at the transcript this morning, because we just got it this morning, I saw some of that. We now recognizethe gentle lady from Texas. Or excuse me, Pennsylvania. I'm used to you being down there. The gentle lady from Pennsylvania. MADELEINE DEAN, U.S. HOUSE DEMOCRAT: I got an upgrade.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Mr. Hur. Thank you, Chairman. Thank you, Mr. Hur for your service to our country, for your team's service in this investigation. Youdetermined after what you described as rigorous, detailed and thorough analysis that President Biden should not be prosecuted for mishandling classified documents. In fact, everybody can take a look at your report. The very first sentence says as much. It says, quote, "We conclude that no criminal charges are warranted in this matter." Am I correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: That's the bottom line of this report. Am I correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: That is the first sentence.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: It's the first sentence in the bottom line. There's an awful lot of misinformation that has been put forward by the press in some cases, andalso by the other side of this dais. You didn't reach this decision because President Biden was sympathetic. Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I reached the decision based on the totality of the reasons that I set forth at length in my report.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Based on the evidence. And while Mr. Trump, who is being prosecuted, is not sympathetic, you didn't calibrate any of that in there. Sympathetic,not sympathetic. Doesn't matter. It's the evidence, right?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: Congresswoman, I did not reach any assessments of the evidence in the Trump matter to the extent that I considered the allegations against formerPresident Trump. It was for purposes of comparing relevant precedents.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: I trust that with your credibility, you were not out to get Mr. Trump nor here to help Mr. Biden. I think it's about the evidence. And I thinkyou say that over and over again in your report. Why did you decide President Biden should not be prosecuted? Your report tells us, quote, "We conclude the evidence is not sufficient to convict. Those are your words." Is that correct?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I believe if those exact words do not appear in the report, that is consistent with the gist of my conclusion.

utterances.speaker: DEAN
utterances.sentences: Very good. They are your exact words. That was not the case with Donald Trump. You have a copy of your report today, don't you? In front ofyou?

utterances.speaker: HUR
utterances.sentences: I do.
